Context:
Program Name: Hearing Instrument Specialist
Code: S117
Credential: Ontario College Advanced Diploma
Duration: 3 years (6 semesters)
Starting Months: September
Domestic Tuition: $4,887.00
International Tuition: $18,226.00
Method of Study: Full-time
Location: Waterfront Campus
Experiential Learning: Clinical or field education in semesters 3, 4, 5 and 6
Fall 2023 Delivery: Semester 1, 3, 5 - On Campus; Winter 2024 Delivery: Semester 2, 4 - Hybrid; Semester 6 - On Campus
Related Programs: Dental Hygiene (S134), Practical Nursing (PN) (S121), Orthotic / Prosthetic Technician (S102)
Program Description: Preparing qualified hearing professionals for nearly 30 years. The program will provide opportunities to study and develop clinical skills to test hearing, select appropriate hearing instruments, and dispense these aids to those in need. For applicants with a relevant degree or diploma, there is an opportunity for advanced standing into semester 3 of the program.

Key Information: The Hearing Instrument Specialist (S117) program at George Brown College is a full-time, three-year advanced diploma program that teaches clinical and people skills needed to work in this field. It provides opportunities to study and develop the skills required to test hearing, select appropriate hearing instruments, and dispense these aids to those in need. The program is available at the Waterfront Campus. The tuition for domestic students is $4,887.00 and for international students is $18,226.00 per year. The program includes experiential learning with clinical or field education in semesters 3, 4, 5, and 6. The delivery methods for the fall of 2023 are on campus for semesters 1, 3, and 5, while winter 2024 is hybrid for semester 2 and 4 and on campus for semester 6. Related programs include Dental Hygiene (S134), Practical Nursing (PN) (S121), and Orthotic / Prosthetic Technician (S102). The program has been running for nearly 30 years and offers advanced standing into semester 3 for applicants with a relevant degree or diploma.

Context:
Program Information:
- The text suggests a program in Hearing Instrument Specialist at the college.
- Students will study hearing instrument sciences and develop clinical skills.
- Topics covered include acoustics, audiometric testing, selection and fitting of hearing aids, and hearing aid technology.
- Soft skills like active listening, empathy, and effective communication are also developed.
- Additional courses cover clinic management, health promotion, counselling, and entrepreneurial mindset.

Educational Requirements:
- Applicants with a bachelor's degree or diploma in Health Sciences, Social Sciences, or related fields and an overall average of B minus (or 2.7 GPA or 70%) may be considered for advanced standing into semester 3 of the program.

Field Education:
- Field placement is a component of the Hearing Instrument Specialist program.
- Students will conduct a 21-hour on-site placement at the WAVE Hearing Clinic and a 7-week (equivalent to 245 hours) off-site placement with a community partner.
- Students are responsible for finding their own field experience opportunities but will be supported in this process.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Hearing Instrument Specialist Program S117 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
Extracted Information:

1. The program does not provide field experience opportunities directly, but faculty will support students in finding their own opportunities.
2. External field education generally occurs in the Greater Toronto Area, and may require travel within the province. Students are responsible for associated costs.
3. Interested students with lower competitive marks can consider enrolling in the Pre-Health Sciences Pathway to Advanced Diplomas and Degrees (A108) program.
4. Career options for Hearing Instrument Specialist graduates include clinical, manufacturing, training, and self-employment.
5. In Ontario, hearing aids may only be dispensed by prescription from a professional authorized by the Regulated Health Professions Act.
6. Graduates are eligible for full membership in the Association of Hearing Instrument Practitioners of Ontario (AHIP) as a hearing instrument dispenser (HID). They must pay annual dues and complete 1,000 hours of practical work and international licensing exam to become full members.
7. Full HIS members of AHIP can apply to become a hearing aid authorizer under the Ontario Ministry of Health's Assistive Devices Program (ADP).
8. Semester 1 courses include Clinical Acoustics (HEAR 1001), Introduction to Hearing Instrument Sciences (HEAR 1003), Functional Anatomy and Physiology (HEAR 1013), Ethics and Professionalism (HEAR 1014), Gerontology (HEAR 1016), and Introduction to College Communication (COMM 1000) if necessary.
9. Semester 2 courses are not mentioned in the provided text.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Hearing Instrument Specialist Program S117 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
The text provides a list of courses offered in Semesters 2 to 6 for the Hearing Instrument Specialist program at the college. Here is the extracted information:

Semester 2:
- HEAR 1002: Hearing Disorders
- HEAR 1009: Hearing Technology I: Linear to Digital Evolution
- HEAR 1010: Hearing Testing I: Introduction to Audiometry
- HEAR 1011: Psycho-social Impact of Hearing Loss
- COMM 2000: Communicating Across Context
- GNED: General Education Elective

Semester 3:
- HEAR 1015: Fundamental Skills for HIS
- HEAR 2016: Hearing Instrument Technology II: Programming and ANSI Testing
- HEAR 2010: Hearing Testing II: Intermediate Audiometry and Masking
- HEAR 2012: Interviewing and Counselling
- HEAR 2022: Hearing Clinic I
- GNED: General Education Elective

Semester 4:
- HEAR 2019: Hearing Instrument Technology III: Real Ear Measurement
- HEAR 2021: Hearing Testing III: Advanced Audiometry
- HEAR 2014: Business Management I: Introduction and Marketing
- HEAR 2023: Hearing Clinic II
- GNED: General Education Elective

Semester 5:
- HEAR 3001: Hearing Instrument Technology IV: Hearing Instrument Features & Case Studies
- HEAR 3003: Field Placement & Workplace Preparation
- HEAR 3014: Business Management II: Finance & Planning
- HEAR 3020: Hearing Clinic III

Semester 6:
- HEAR 3025: Hearing Clinic IV
- HEAR 3029: Applied Counselling & Health Promotion
- HEAR 3028: Hearing Instrument Technology V: Product Update
- HEAR 3027: Community Field Placement

Additionally, students may be required to take COMM 1000 (Introduction to College Communication) before progressing to COMM 2000. This course does not count as a required course for graduation and will incur an additional charge. Students are encouraged to visit the Assessment Centre for more information.

General Education Electives are also included in the program but no specific courses were mentioned in the text.

Context:
The text provides information on the roles and responsibilities of a Hearing Instrument Specialist and the tuition fees for the program at George Brown College. Here's the extracted information:

- Roles and Responsibilities of a Hearing Instrument Specialist:
  - Take accurate ear mould impressions based on otoscopic examination
  - Advocate and effectively communicate psycho-social implications of hearing loss
  - Design hearing health-care plans incorporating health promotion, rehabilitation, and appropriate referrals
  - Verify benefits of recommended devices using appropriate technology
  - Fit and adjust hearing devices based on client observation, acoustical needs, and counselling
  - Teach use and maintenance of hearing aids and assistive listening devices to clients and others
  - Maintain, repair, and modify assistive hearing devices for optimal performance
  - Recommend appropriate hearing devices based on manufacturers' specifications and features
  - Treat, counsel, and communicate effectively with all clients
  - Determine effective management practices for a hearing aid dispensary
  - Research and evaluate current community and government resources, new technologies, and medical advances
  - Participate collaboratively as an integral member of the interprofessional healthcare team
- Tuition Fees:
  - Domestic Students: $4,887.00 for the first two semesters (Fall 2022)
  - International Students: $18,226.00 for the first two semesters (Fall 2023)
- Additional Information:
  - Fees are subject to change for programs starting in Fall 2023 and later dates.
  - Financial assistance is available through OSAP for eligible applicants.
  - The information on this website is subject to change without notice, and students should verify fee requirements.
- Admission Requirements: Applicants are selected based on unspecified criteria. (No specific admission requirements were mentioned in the text.)
